Back to Ludwig van Beethoven

Ludwig van Beethoven

Twelve Contredanses, WoO 14

1802 · Hess 102 · Biamonti 314

[IMSLP]

Total duration: 7'

  • 1. C major
  • 2. A major
  • 4. B-flat major
  • 5. E-flat major
  • 7. E-flat major
  • 8. C major
  • 9. A major
  • 10. C major
  • 12. E-flat major

These are piano versions of orchestral dances. The orchestral version has twelve dances; six were arranged for piano and published in Beethoven’s lifetime (nos. 8, 7, 4, 10, 9 and 1, in this ordering), and three more were also arranged for piano but not published (nos. 2, 5 and 12). The other three dances (nos. 3, 6 and 11) were apparently never arranged for piano. All nine of the arrangements are possibly spurious.

Recommended editions

  • Henle · HN 449 · Tänze für Klavier · ed. Robert Forster [nos. 1–2, 4–5, 7 and 9–10]
  • Könemann · K 197 · Tänze · ed. István Máriássy
  • Breitkopf & Härtel · Supplemente zur Gesamtausgabe VIII / Original-Klavierauszüge eigener Werke · ed. Willy Hess

1. C major

This arrangement is the sixth of the published collection.

Duration: 0' 30"

Difficulty: 1.5

2. A major

Duration: 0' 30"

Difficulty: 1.5

4. B-flat major

This arrangement is the third of the published collection.

Duration: 0' 30"

Difficulty: 1.5

5. E-flat major

Duration: 1'

Difficulty: 1.5

7. E-flat major

This arrangement is the second of the published collection. Beethoven used the same theme in the variations and fugue in E-flat major, op. 35, the finale of the ballet Die Geschöpfe des Prometheus (op. 43), and the finale of the symphony no. 3 (op. 55).

Duration: 0' 30"

Difficulty: 1.5

8. C major

This arrangement is the first of the published collection.

Duration: 0' 30"

Difficulty: 2

9. A major

This arrangement is the fifth of the published collection.

Duration: 0' 30"

Difficulty: 1.5

10. C major

This arrangement is the fourth of the published collection.

Duration: 1'

Difficulty: 2

12. E-flat major

Duration: 2'

Difficulty: 2
